messages.content:
You are a world state generator for a workplace benchmark. Your job is to transform an abstract scenario into a concrete, detailed world_state JSON.

The world_state should include:
1. All metadata from the scenario (scenario_id, description, noise_level, depth, global_settings, people, projects)
2. sub_scenarios_expanded: For each abstract sub_scenario from the input scenario, create a concrete expanded version with:
   - Concrete ISO datetime timestamps
   - Specific participant IDs/emails
   - Detailed event descriptions
   - Any seeds needed for data generation
   - This array should contain ONLY the expanded versions of the sub_scenarios listed in the input scenario
3. noise_scenarios: An array of noise-only scenario objects that are NOT part of the core sub_scenarios:
   - These should be realistic but unrelated workplace events/messages/activities
   - Each noise scenario should have similar structure to sub_scenarios_expanded (id, type, timestamps, participants, etc.)
   - The number of noise scenarios should scale with the noise_level parameter

IMPORTANT: Do NOT include per_source_plans in the world_state. The world_state is scenario-centric only.

IMPORTANT PARAMETERS:
- noise_level (0-1): Controls amount of unrelated/off-task data
  * 0 = almost no noise, only data directly relevant to sub_scenarios (noise_scenarios should be empty or minimal)
  * 1 = lots of unrelated messages/events/files (still realistic) (noise_scenarios should contain many entries)
- depth (0-1): Controls how indirect the evidence is
  * 0 = sub_scenario realized directly (e.g., one clear Slack message)
  * 1 = sub_scenario requires multi-step, multi-source chaining to infer
  * Intermediate values interpolate behavior

CRITICAL: sub_scenarios_expanded must correspond exactly to the sub_scenarios in the input scenario. All other unrelated scenarios should go in noise_scenarios.

You must output ONLY valid JSON matching the world_state schema. Do not include markdown code fences.

raw_message.content:

    {

          "timestamp": "2025-11-14T09:18:00+09:00",
          "channel": "email",
          "context_id": "gmail_dat_migration_planning_002",
          "from": "alex.smith@company.com",
          "to": [
            "morgan.garcia@company.com"
          ],
          "cc": [
            "sam.williams@company.com"
          ],
          "subject": "Re: Data Migration Planning milestone / kickoff",
          "body": "Hi Morgan,\n\nI was looking at the DAT project milestones and noticed that the Planning milestone is set for 2025-11-10 but we still haven’t had a proper cross-team planning discussion with Engineering.\n\nCould we line up a session early next week during working hours to go over Data Migration scope and dependencies? I’d like Jordan from your team there, and I’ll bring Sam from R&D. I’m thinking ~45 minutes should be enough if we stay focused.\n\nRough preference would be sometime between Tuesday and Thursday next week, between 10:00 and 17:00 Korea time, but I’m flexible if Jordan has constraints.\n\nIf you’re okay with this, I can send a separate thread proposing specific times and loop Jordan in directly.\n\nThanks,\nAlex\n\nAlex Smith\nPM, R&D",
          "description": "Alex flags the need for a planning session with Engineering to Morgan, specifying Jordan and Sam as the key attendees, and suggests a 45-minute meeting next week during working hours.",
          "related_project": "DAT"
        },

Jordan is the right person from Engineering.\n\nJordan usually has their daily standup 10:00–10:20 and a recurring infra sync Wednesday 15:00–15:30. Outside of that, Tuesday–Thursday next week should be mostly open.\n\nGo ahead and propose a few 45-min slots and cc Jordan. I’ll join if I can, but I don’t have to be mandatory.\n\nBest,\nMorgan\n\nMorgan Garcia\nEngineering Manager",
          "description": "Morgan confirms Jordan as the Engineering representative and provides constraints, asking Alex to propose 45-minute slots and include Jordan.",
          "related_project": "DAT"
        },

          "event_id": "planning_meeting_context_2_email_3",

          "context_id": "gmail_dat_migration_planning_002",

            "sam.williams@company.com"

          "subject": "Data Migration planning discussion – early next week",
          "body": "Hi Jordan, hi Sam,\n\nFollowing up on the Data Migration Planning milestone: Morgan and I think we should get together for a focused planning session next week to nail down the migration approach, risks, and dependencies.\n\nI’m aiming for a 45-minute meeting sometime early next week (Asia/Seoul working hours). Could you both let me know which of these windows work for you?\n\n- Tue 2025-11-18, 10:30–11:15\n- Wed 2025-11-19, 11:00–11:45\n- Thu 2025-11-20, 16:00–16:45\n\nIf none of those work, feel free to suggest nearby times. Once we converge on a slot I’ll send a calendar invite titled “DAT – Data Migration Planning (Alex / Jordan / Sam)”.\n\nThanks,\nAlex",

          ],
          "cc": [
            "sam.williams@company.com",
            "morgan.garcia@company.com"
          ],
          "subject": "Re: Data Migration planning discussion – early next week",
          "body": "Hi Alex,\n\nThanks for looping me in.\n\nMy schedule next week in KST:\n- Tue 2025-11-18, 10:30–11:15: Works (I’m free right after daily standup).\n- Wed 2025-11-19, 11:00–11:45: Also works.\n- Thu 2025-11-20, 16:00–16:45: I’m blocked with a release dry run.\n\nSo same as Sam: Tuesday or Wednesday is fine, Thursday doesn’t work.\n\nJordan",

          "channel": "email",
          "context_id": "gmail_dat_migration_planning_002",

          "body": "Perfect, thanks both.\n\nSince Tuesday 10:30–11:15 works for everyone and is closer to the Planning milestone, let’s lock that in.\n\nI’ll send a calendar invite for:\n\nTitle: DAT – Data Migration Planning (Alex / Jordan / Sam)\nDate: Tue 2025-11-18\nTime: 10:30–11:15 (Asia/Seoul)\n\nAgenda will be:\n1) Review of current DAT-100 / DAT-101 work\n2) Outline migration phases\n3) Identify risks and dependencies\n4) Next steps & owners\n\nBest,\nAlex",
